issues.text: Whether after the coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 there are no reversioners and no reversionary rights and a suit for a declaration that the alienation is not binding on the reversioners is no longer maintainable

anchor.surface_text: the Hindu Succession Act. 1956 came into force. At the hearing of the appeal before the High Court, the alienees raised the preliminary contention that after the coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, there are no reversioners and no reversionary rights, and a suit for a declaration that the alienation is not binding on the reversioners is no longer maintainable.

issues.text: Whether the three sons of Mst. Indrawati and the two sons of Mst. Radha Rani are improperly joined as respondents Nos. 8 to 12 in the petition of appeal

anchor.surface_text: The first preliminary objection is that the three sons of Mst. Indrawati and the two sons of Mst. Radha Rani are improperly joined as respondents Nos. 8 to 12 in the petition of appeal. Respondents Nos. 8 to 12 were not parties to the appeal before the High Court, nor was any order obtained permitting their joinder in the appeal to this Court.

issues.text: Whether the petition of appeal is a nullity as Mst. Bhagwati, a dead person was impleaded as a party respondent therein

anchor.surface_text: The next preliminary objection is that the petition of appeal is a nullity as Mst. Bhagwati, a dead person was impleaded as a party respondent therein. As Mst. Bhagwati was dead on the date of the filing of the petition of appeal, she could not be shown as a respondent in this appeal.

issues.text: Whether the appeal is defectively constituted and is not maintainable in the absence of the heirs of Mst. Bhagwati

anchor.surface_text: the appeal is defectively constituted and is not maintainable in the absence of the heirs of Mst. Bhagwati. The heirs of Mst. Bhagwati are Mst. Radha Rani and the sons and daughters of Mst. Indrawati. The appellant did not obtain any order of Court substituting the heirs of Mst. Bhagwati in her place.

In this connection, it is necessary to consider whether the heirs of the widow were necessary parties to a suit against the alienee either for a declaration that the alienation is void beyond her lifetime or for possession of the alienated property.

arguments.claim: Heirs of widow not necessary parties to declaratory suit post widow's death during pendency

anchor.surface_text: Though the widow was joined as a party to the suit, no relief was claimed against her personally. On the death of the widow, the entire estate of the last full owner is represented by the plaintiff suing in a representative capacity on behalf of all the reversioners, and the plaintiff can get effective relief against the alienee in the absence of the heirs of the widow.

arguments.claim: Proviso to S.42 Specific Relief Act does not bar declaratory suit by reversioner; can continue without amendment even if entitled to possession post widow death

anchor.surface_text: As the reversioners were not entitled to the possession of the property at the time of the institution of the suit, the next reversioner could then sue for a bare declaration and the proviso to S. 42 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877 did not constitute a bar to the suit.

arguments.claim: Reversioners could sue alienee for possession post widow death without joining her heirs

anchor.surface_text: To such a suit by the reversioners for possession of the property after the death of the widow, the heirs of the widow were not necessary parties. The reversioners could claim no relief against the heirs of the widow and could effectively obtain the relief claimed against the alienee in their absence.

arguments.claim: Appeal not defective despite abatement against Bhagwati; proceeds against surviving respondents; no inconsistent decrees

anchor.surface_text: The appeal against the surviving respondents has not abated, and we think that the appeal is not defectively constituted in the absence of the heirs of Mst. Bhagwati. In the appeal to this Court, Mst. Radha Rani asks for the identical relief which the original plaintiff sought in the suit.

holdings.text: Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 did not apply to properties in the possession of alienees under an alienation made by the Hindu female before the Act came into force, and sections 14, 15 and 16 of the Act did not abolish the reversioners and reversionary rights in respect of such properties.

anchor.surface_text: s. 14 did number apply to properties in the possession of alienees under an alienation made by the Hindu female before the Act came into force, and in respect of such properties, ss. 14, 15 and 16 of the Act did number abolish the reversioners and reversionary rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed precedents Gummalapura Taggina Mattada Kotturuswami and Brahmadeo Singh; distinguished Patna and Allahabad High Court views; High Court erred in holding suit not maintainable post-Act.

holdings.text: It is open to a reversioner to maintain a suit for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female limited owner before the coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, was without legal necessity and was not binding upon the reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: it is open to a reversioner to maintain a suit for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female limited owner before the companying into force of the Hindu Succession Act., 1956, was without legal necessity and was number binding upon the reversioners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Effect of Brahmadeo Singh decision; directly applies to facts where alienation in 1919 pre-dates 1956 Act.

holdings.text: The names of respondents Nos. 8 to 12 (three sons of Mst. Indrawati and two sons of Mst. Radha Rani) be struck off from the record as improperly joined.

holdings.reasoning_summary: They were not parties to High Court appeal; no order for joinder; appellant consents.

holdings.text: The petition of appeal is not a nullity merely because Mst. Bhagwati, a dead person, was impleaded as respondent; the appeal may proceed against the other respondents on the footing that Mst. Bhagwati is not a party.

anchor.surface_text: But the appeal may proceed against the other respondents on the footing that Mst. Bhagwati is number a party to the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural irregularity does not vitiate entire appeal; proceeds against surviving respondents.

holdings.text: The heirs of the widow are not necessary parties to a suit by reversioners against the alienee for possession of the alienated property after the death of the widow.

anchor.surface_text: To such a suit by the reversioners for possession of the property after the death of the widow, the heirs of the widow were number necessary parties. The reversioners companyld claim numberrelief against the heirs of the widow and companyld effectively obtain the relief claimed against the alienee in their absence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed Bijoy Gopal Mukherji; no relief claimed against heirs; effective relief against alienee possible.

holdings.text: In the case of the death of the widow during the pendency of the declaratory suit by the next reversioner, the heirs of the widow are not necessary parties to the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Though the widow was joined as a party to the suit, numberrelief was claimed against her personally. holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff represents all reversioners; no personal relief against widow; effective relief obtainable; plaint need not be amended.

holdings.text: The proviso to Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877 did not constitute a bar to the declaratory suit by the next reversioner, and the suit can continue without amendment even if reversioners become entitled to possession during pendency.

anchor.surface_text: As the reversioners were number entitled to the possession of the property at the time of the institution of the suit, the next reversioner companyld then sue for a bare declaration and the proviso to S. 42 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877 did number companystitute a bar to the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit instituted when only declaration available; subsequent entitlement does not defect suit or require amendment; Illustration e supports.

holdings.text: The appeal is not defectively constituted in the absence of the heirs of Mst. Bhagwati due to abatement against her; it can proceed against surviving respondents without leading to inconsistent decrees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Abatement only against deceased; identical relief sought; no decree in favor of Bhagwati; no conflict possible.

holdings.text: We hold that the appeal is not defective on account of the non-joinder of necessary parties.

In the last case, the trial Court had decreed a suit by the reversioners for a declaration that two sale deeds executed by a Hindu widow were without legal necessity and number binding upon them. The Patna

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 14 did number apply to properties in the possession of alienees under an alienation made by the Hindu female before the Act came into force, and in respect of such properties, ss. 14, 15 and 16 of the Act did number abolish the reversioners and reversionary rights

precedents.citation: Brahmadeo Singh and another v. Deomani Missir and others 2

anchor.surface_text: and this opinion was followed by this Court in Brahmadeo Singh and another v. Deomani Missir and others 2 . In the last case, the trial Court had decreed a suit by the reversioners for a declaration that two sale deeds executed by a Hindu widow were without legal necessity and number binding upon them. The Patna High Court allowed an appeal by the alienees and dismissed the suit holding that by reason of the provisions of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, a suit by a reversioner for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female is number binding on the reversioner is number maintainable. From the decision of the Patna High Court the reversioners preferred an appeal to this Court.

precedents.case_name: Brahmadeo Singh and another v Deomani Missir and others
precedents.cited_proposition: S. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 did number extend to property already alienated by a Hindu female

precedents.citation: Ramsaroop Singh and others v. Hiralal Singh and others -

anchor.surface_text: This Court held that the view taken by the Patna High Court following its earlier decision in Ramsaroop Singh and others v. Hiralal Singh and others -  and of the Allahabad High Court in Hanuman Prasad v. Indrawati 4   the decision under appeal in this case  was incorrect, and S. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 did number extend to property already alienated by a Hindu female. This Court accordingly allowed the appeal, and reversed the decree of the Patna High Court. The effect of this decision is that it is open to a reversioner to maintain a suit for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female limited owner before the companying into force of the Hindu Succession Act., 1956, was without legal necessity and was number binding upon the reversioners.

precedents.case_name: Ramsaroop Singh and others v Hiralal Singh and others
precedents.cited_proposition: by reason of the provisions of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, a suit by a reversioner for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female is number binding on the reversioner is number maintainable

anchor.surface_text: in Ramsaroop Singh and others v. Hiralal Singh and others -  and of the Allahabad High Court in Hanuman Prasad v. Indrawati 4   the decision under appeal in this case  was incorrect, and S. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 did number extend to property already alienated by a Hindu female. This Court accordingly allowed the appeal, and reversed the decree of the Patna High Court. The effect of this decision is that it is open to a reversioner to maintain a suit for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female limited owner before the companying into force of the Hindu Succession Act., 1956, was without legal necessity and was number binding upon the reversioners. It follows that the High Court was in error in holding that the present suit was number maintainable since the companying into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956.

precedents.cited_proposition: by reason of the provisions of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, a suit by a reversioner for a declaration that an alienation made by a Hindu female is number binding on the reversioner is number maintainable

To such a suit by the reversioners for possession of the property after the death of the widow, the heirs of the widow were number necessary parties. The reversioners companyld claim numberrelief against the heirs of the widow and companyld effectively obtain the relief claimed against the alienee in their absence. Instead of waiting until her death, the next reversioner as representing all the reversioners of the last full owner companyld institute a suit against the alienee for a declaration that the alienation was without legal necessity and was void beyond her lifetime.

precedents.case_name: Bijoy Gopal Mukherji v Krishna Mahishi Debi
precedents.cited_proposition: the reversioners were number bound to institute a declaratory suit during the lifetime of the widow. They companyld wait until her death and then sue the alienee for possession of the alienated property treating the alienation as a nullity without the intervention of any Court
